results.title: Un Homme Qui Dort = a Man Who Sleeps
results.brief_description:
A student refuses to carry on with his studies and decides to live ‘in neutral time’ or at the limit of schizophrenia. Reference: Film Index International.

Credits: Director, Bernard Queysanne ; writers, Bernard Queysanne, Georges Perec ; photography, Bernard Zitzermann ; music, Philippe Drogoz, Eugenie Kuffler.
Cast: Jacques Spiesser, Ludmila Mikael.

results.title: Les Mysteres de Paris (TV Version) = the Mysteries of Paris
results.brief_description:
This version of Sue’s novel was originally conceived as a live-to-air production. Rodolphe de Sombreuil runs over a poor man in the streets and promises he will look after his young daughter. Sombreuil disguises himself as a working-class man and goes looking for Fleur de Marie who has been kidnapped by shady underworld characters. He is appalled by the squalor in which people live in the depressing working class slums.

Credits: Director, Marcel Cravenne ; writers, Claude Santelli ; photography, Maurice Barry ; music, Maurice Jarre.
Cast: Clotilde Joano, Marcel Bozzuffi, Jacques Dacqmine, Edmond Beauchamp, Georgette Anys, Jacques Marin, Francois Chaumette, Denise Gence, Veronique Silver, Maria Mauban, Claude Pieplu, Francois Maistre, Maria Meriko, Victor Lanoux, Clara Daquin.

results.title: Adorable Menteuse = Such an Adorable Liar
results.brief_description:
Juliette and Sophie share an apartment. Juliette is a garrulous 18-year-old girl who can’t go five minutes without telling a lie. She spies on her upstairs neighbour, a man of 40, pretending she is in love with him … until the day she really is. She vows to reform and speak nothing but the truth. But her reputation precedes her and her gentleman friend refuses to take anything she says seriously.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Michel Deville ; writers, Nina Companeez, Michel Deville ; photography, Claude Lecomte ; music, Jean Dalve.
Cast: Marina Vlady, Macha Meril, Ginette Letondal, Jean-Marc Bory, Michel Vitold, Jean-Francois Calve, Claude Nicot, Michel Lonsdale, Christian Alers.

results.title: Un Milliard Dans Un Billard = a Million in a Billiard Table
results.brief_description:
In Switzerland, a bored bank teller and his inventor friend are planning a jewellery heist. Little do they know that a young American tourist they met earlier is also a jewel thief and planning to rob the same outlet.

Credits: Producer, Maurice Jacquin ; director, Nicolas Gessner ; writers, Nicolas Gessner, Charles Spaak ; photography, Claude lecomte ; music, Georges Garvarentz.
Cast: Jean Seberg, Claude Rich, Elsa Martinelli, Pierre Vernier, Jacques Morel.

results.title: La Chasse Royale = Royal Hunt
results.brief_description:
Story of love between a young girl and a hunter in the Tatra Mountain of Czechoslovakia. Reference: Film Index International.

Credits: Director, Francois Leterrier ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Zdenek Liska.
Cast: Sami Frey, Ludmilla Mikael, Claude Brasseur, Suzanne Flon.

results.title: Tirez Sur le Pianiste = Shoot the Piano Player (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Francois Truffaut, Pierre Braunberger and Films de la Pleiade
results.brief_description:
An ex-concert pianist, working in a seedy bar gets involved with gangsters when he helps his two petty crook brothers escape from them, an action culminating in the death of his girlfriend. This film, more than any other, reflects the influence of Hollywood low-budget melodramas on Truffaut and his cinematic style.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, Francois Truffaut ; writers, Francois Truffaut, Marcel Moussy , photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Charles Aznavour, Marie Dubois, Nicole Berger, Albert Remy, Michele Mercier, Daniel Boulanger, Alice Sapritch, Boby Lapointe.

results.title: Richard et Cosima
results.creator_credit: Peter Patzak, Dietrich Mack and Rene Letzgus
results.brief_description:
Having persuaded the King that a new theater should be built to accomodate the performances of his tetralogy, Wagner and Cosima settle in a villa near Bayreuth, called ‘Wahnfried’. The film recounts Wagner’s often stormy relationship with Cosima.

Credits: Producers, Rene Letzgus, Dietrich mack ; director, Peter Patzak ; writers, Reinard Baumgart ; photography, Anton Peschke ; music, Peter Zwetkoff.
Cast: Otto Sander, Tatja Seibt, Fabienne Babe.

results.title: Bob le Flambeur = Bob the Gambler
results.brief_description:
Bob, a retired bank robber and compulsive gambler masterminds a raid on the casino at Deauville to cover his gambling debts. The film is a homage to American cinema, namely John Huston, through the underlying motif of failure. For instance, the ending of ‘Bob le Flambeur’ is very similar to ‘Beat the Devil’ and the scene where one of the protagonist dies in a horse enclosure is reminiscent of ‘The Asphalt Jungle’. What is astonishing is how much the gritty, free-wheeling camera style predates the French New Wave. Everything is already here, the jump-cuts, jazzy score and visual quotes. This is the kind of film that we want to make! exclaimed the young and rebellious Francois Truffaut in 1955. Godard acknowledged Melville’s influence, giving him an extended cameo in ‘A bout de souffle’ (‘Breathless’). Melville’s influence has also been acknowledged by foreign filmmaker such as Quentin Tarantino and John Woo. Melville only had a small budget for this film and could only afford three lights. The lack of lighting being a hindrance for depth of film, most of the backgrounds appear soft on the screen. This effect became a trademark of the film and made Henri Decae a director of photography in high demand.

Credits: Producer, Florence Melville ; director, Jean-Pierre Melville ; writers, Jean-Pierre Melville, Auguste Le Breton ; photography, Henri Decae ; music, Eddie Barclay, Jo Boyer ; costumes, Ted Lapidus.
Cast: Isabel Corey, Roger Duchesne, Daniel Cauchy, Guy Decomble, Simone Paris, Andre Garet, Claude Cerval, Colette Fleury, Gerard Buhr, Howard Vernon.

results.title: Petit a Petit
results.brief_description:
Damoure and Lam leave Niger to travel to Paris in order to investigate the possibility of building a multi-storey building in Niamey. This is a pretext for Rouch and his interprets to cast a caustic look at French society and to indulge in largely improvised reversed ethnology. During their research trip in Paris, Damoure and Lam meet up with a young African prostitute, a bum and a young woman who is bored with her life to whom they extend an invitation to come and spend time in Niger with them.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, Jean Rouch ; writer, Jean Rouch ; photography, Jean Rouch ; music, Enos Amelolon, Amicale de Niamey, Alan Helly.
Cast: Safi Faye, Damoure Zika, Lam Ibrahim Dia, Illo Gaoudel, Ariane Bruneton, Tallou Mouzourane.

results.title: Le Grand Jeu = the Full Deck
results.brief_description:
Scripted by frequent Feyder collaborator Charles Spaak, the film focuses on lawyer Pierre Martel, who runs up huge debts to help keep his mistress, Florence, in style. In order to avoid charges of embezzlement, Pierre signs up with the Foreign Legion intending to ‘forget’. Soon after he meets Blanche who reads cards and predicts he will be reunited with his beloved. Pierre begins keeping time with Irma, a prostitute suffering of amnesia, who looks strangely like Florence, only as a brunette. In order to accentuate the doubt of the hero obsessed by two women, similar in many ways, yet different, Feyder had Mary Bell’s voice as Irma dubbed by Claude Marcy. ‘Le grand jeu’ is one of Feyder’s more interesting. Its ‘realist-poetic’ sensitivity - seedy decors and world-weary characters - is greatly enhanced by wonderful performances, especially by Rosay.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau, “The companion to French cinema”, London: BFI Publishing, 1996, p. 76. Robert Siodmak directed a re-make of ‘Le grand jeu’ in 1954.

Credits: Director, Jacques Feyder ; writers, Jacques Feyder, Charles Spaak ; photography, Harry Stradling ; music, Hanns Eisler ; art director, Lazare Meerson ; assistant director, Marcel Carne.
Cast: Pierre-Richard Willm, Mary Bell, Francoise Rosay, Charles Vanel, Georges Pitoeff, Pierre Larquey.
